column8: Pre-calculated and pre-stored summaries that are stored in the data warehouse to improve query performance.
AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript + XML)
A notice message which is generated based on a user specified condition on a metric in a report or dashboard. It may also be a notice that a particular report or indicator has been refreshed.
Analytic reports are used primarily for making key business decisions. Examples of analytic processing include trend analysis and period-to-period comparisons.
The set of rows returned to the end user as a result of a SQL expression presented to a relational DBMS.
Application Service Provider (provider of outsourced web application like SalesForce.com)
A column in a dimension table.    Examples of attributes are customer name, address, city, zip code, state and country.  These are attributes of customer dimension.
Average Unit Price
A software application, typically resident on both the client and the server, that assists in the production data extract process.  Compare with front end tool.
Business Activity Monitoring
Billings, Bookings, and Backlogs
Business Objects Broadcast Agent
Business Process Re-engineering
Business Requirements Document
A SELECT DISTINCT query on a single dimension table to enumerate the values of an attribute.
A generic term which describes leveraging the organization's internal and external data assets for making better business decisions.  Also known as Decision Support.
Swiss bank account for Products
Swiss bank account for Services
Cost Of Goods Sold
Business rules and formats
A key in a database table made up of several fields. Same as concatenated key.
see composite key.
Configure To Order
A name for a multi-dimensional database, usually referring to the simple case of product, market, and time.
A dashboard refers to a display area where reports, indicators and shared documents are available for viewing.
The process of copying data from a legacy system in order to load it into a data warehouse.
The form of the data in the database. Data items can exist in many formats such as text, integer and floating-point decimal.

A collection of specific facts and associated dimensions which help analyze a business' performance and issues A Data Mart (also known as a Subject Area repository) is usually specific to a business department.  Examples of Data Marts are a Marketing Data Mart, Sales Data Mart, and Finance Data Mart.

An information extraction activity whose goal is to discover hidden facts contained in data. Using a combination of machine learning, statistical analysis, modeling techniques and database technology, data mining finds patterns and subtle relationships in data and infers rules that allow the prediction of future results. Typical applications include market segmentation, customer profiling, fraud detection, evaluation of retail promotions, and credit risk analysis.

A copy of transaction data specifically structured for query and analysis.  A corporate data warehouse could be viewed as a collection of multiple data repositories combined together using common dimensions.
The activity of using data to make decisions in an organization.

An independent entity in the model of an organization that serves as an entry point or as a mechanism for describing the additive measures of the organization.  Dimensions are mostly the textual contexts surrounding a fact that are true at the moment the fact is recorded. Examples of dimensions are Product, Customer, and Marketing Campaign. Dates are also dimensions.
A table in a star join schema with a single part primary key. A dimension table contains columns with descriptive information.
A set of databases for decision support designed as star joined schemas.
A data item that has a finite set of values. Discrete is the opposite of continuous.
The act of requesting data from two or more fact tables in a value chain in a single report.
The act of adding a row header or replacing a row header in a report to break down the rows of the answer set in a greater detail.
The act of removing a row header or replacing a row header in a report to group the rows of the answer set in less detail.
Enterprise Application Integration -- often rely on Web Services to transform data for a single transaction from one format to another.
Enterprise Application Services
This acronym stands for Executive Information System.  A high level presentation BI tool that uses dashboards, traffic lighting, and other exception management techniques for knowledge distribution.
Entity Relationship Diagram
This acronym stands for Extraction, Transformation, and Load. A technical term used to describe the back end work to gather and load data into a data warehouse.
Data not collected by the organization, such as data available from a reference book, a government source or a proprietary database, that is loaded into the data warehouse.
A measurement, typically numeric and additive, that is stored in a fact table.  Examples of facts are booking, invoice, and forecast.
The central table in a star join schema, characterized by a composite key, containing numeric measurments and foreign keys drawn from dimension tables.
Forecast
A type of application constraint that constrains on the numeric values of one or more facts.
A client tool that fetches or manipulates data stored on a relational database.  Compare with back end tool.
This acronym stands for Graphical User Interface.  A style of computer interface characterized by windows, icons, graphics and the use of a mouse pointing device.

Hierarchy refers to a business organization or structure. For instance a sales region hierarchy may represent Region, Country, State, City, etc. Each of these segments is referred to as Levels. A single dimension table can have multiple hierarchies depending on user requirements. Each of these hierarchies can have different levels.
Hyper Text Transfer Protocol (HTTP), the actual communications protocol that enables Web browsing
Hardware
In PowerAnalyzer, Indicators are used to display key metric values in a dashboard.  PowerAnalyzer three different kinds of indicators: Chart, Table and Gauge.
Internal Sales Order
An operational system for entering data about a company's operations.  May not be a transaction system or a relational system. Usually resides on a mainframe computer.
A logical data relationship in which the value of one data element can exist in combination with many values of another data element, and vice versa.

Any data maintained to support the operations or use of a data warehouse.  Nearly all back end tools and front end tools require some private metadata in the form of specifications or status.  Often the metadata is outside the relational database.  There are no coherent standards for metadata.  Distinguished from the primary data in the dimension tables and fact tables.

Metrics denote a measurement. Analysis of a business process involves measurement of its performance. Metrics are the factors used to evaluate a business process. Sales volume, discounts, number of customers, inventory balance and purchase receipts are some of the examples of metrics. Metrics are always numeric values. Part of fact table.  Examples of metrics/measures that make up facts are Price and Booking Amount.
Marketing Requirements Document
Manufacture To Order
Network Control Services
Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) provides a standard software API method for using database management systems (DBMS).

This acronym stands for Online Analytic Processing.  A term meant to contrast with OLTP.  OLAP is a loosely defined list of principles that provide a dimensional framework for decision support.  The term OLAP also is used to define a confederation of vendors who offer non relational, proprietary products aimed at decision support.
This acronym stands for Online Knowledge Management.  A system that allows the organization, management, and presentation of enterprise knowledge.

This acronym stands for Online Transaction Processing.  The original description for all the activities and systems associated with entering data reliably into a database.  Most frequently used with reference to relational databases, although OLTP can be used generically to describe any transaction processing environment.
A logical data relationship in which the value of one data element can exist in combination with many values of another data element, but not vice versa.
Product Data Master
Changing the arrangement of the rows and columns in a tabular report, where frequently the row or column headings are derived from distinct values in the data itself.
Part Number
Plan Of Record defines the implementation plan for a Product Requirements Document (PRD)
Product Requirements Document developed in response to an Marketing Requirements Document (MED)
A field in a database table that is uniquely different for each record in the table.
A snapshot taken of production data and stored in a data repository at a given period of time.
A user interface effect in a front end tool that displays a list of options for the user.
QAD code is a legacy code for parts from the system before the Oracle ERP system was installed.
This acronym stands for Relational Database Management System.  A system that provides for storage, management and retrieval of data using relational schemas.  Oracle is an example.
A BI tool that allows easy building of reports primarily designed for printing in a structured format.
In PowerAnalyzer, report is a collection of metrics and attributes formatted for viewing through a browser.  This is a change from the typical idea of reports as printed layouts.
A collection of data for a specified purpose in a formalized table or database. Also known as a data store.
Request For Enhancement
Report Of Findings -- Document developed as a response to a BRD.
Roadmap Steering Board -- replaced by SRB
Software as a Service (ASP Model)
The standard description of the ability to access a data warehouse through any of its dimensions equally.
Subject Matter Expert
Software maintenance technical Document
Sales Order

Service Oriented Architecture -- Organizations can use a service oriented architecture to incorporates enterprise-class data transformation and integration services to address complex data integration requirements such as data synchronization and information hubs. SOAs are an evolution from traditional tightly coupled integrations to loosely coupled ones that allow organizations to leverage technology resources as services. New SOAs based on Web Services technologies are addressing the problems of older systems through support for widely accepted standard protocols and data formats. Early examples of SOA technologies include CORBA and DCOM; however, these technologies were never widely adopted because of their close ties to implementation.
Simple Object Access Protocol -- defines the envelope for services and various rules for describing content, and is the preferred protocol for exchanging Web Services.
Sarbanes-Oxley Act
This acronym stands for Standard Query Language.  The standard language for accessing relational databases.
Segment Review Board -- replaced RSB -- 4 to 5 VPs making investment decisions and setting internal directions
A set of reports which are at the detailed transaction level and are used for day to day business operations.  Usually generated from the OLTP systems.  Also known as operational reports.
Total Cost of Ownership
A series of measurements taken at consecutive points in time
A re-expression of the data such as aggregating it, normalizing it, changing its unit of measure, or taking the logarithm of each data item.
Universal Description, Discovery, and Integration -- for creating a directory of Web Services available over the Internet

Universal Data Services -- The Informatica UDS architecture provide a complete service-oriented architecture that includes a wide range of data integration services. UDS is a foundation technology that underlies Informatica products to deliver immediate, accurate, and understandable information from a myriad of complex sources. UDS reduces the complexity across systems, processes, and resources, providing faster time to value for a broad range of data-centric projects, such as data migration, synchronization, hubs, warehousing, and Business Activity Monitoring.
Visualization tools graphically display data to facilitate better understanding of its meaning. Graphical capabilities range from simple scatter plots to complex multi-dimensional representations.
Virtual Profit and Loss

Web Services is used to standardize the interactions between service providers and consumers, Web services can interact with each other without requiring the same implementation language or model, deployment location, or platform. The consumer does not have to know or care about how the service has been implemented, as long as the provider accepts a standard format and returns the result in a standard format. Developers can quickly and easily provide service-enabled application functionality by applying a thin veneer of code without changing the underlying application.
Business Objects -- Tomcat application server with thick client
Web Services Definition Language -- A Web Services standard for describing available Web services
eXtensible Markup Language -- A Web Services standard

XML-RPC is a specification and a set of implementations that allow software running on disparate operating systems, running in different environments to make procedure calls over the Internet. It's remote procedure calling using HTTP as the transport and XML as the encoding.
Business Objects -- Thin Client
see Natural Account.

The financial classification of a particular account. For example: Cash account has an account type of Assets, Airfare has an account type of Expense. Account types Assets, Liabilities, and Equity appear on the Balance Sheet; the others appear on the Profit & Loss Statement.

The number of current employees. This number is derived from the Oracle HR module and posted to the general ledger using the statistical HEADS account. The Data Warehouse contains the general ledger data and uses it for reporting. This number does not include contractors. See Total Head Count.

Process of charging a cost or revenue to a number of business units, products, etc. Allocations can be considered direct if charged above the operating income line and are considered the receiving group's responsibility to manage. Indirect allocations are shown below the operating income line and are considered outside of the receiving group's direct control. The indirect allocations are intended to show the business unit as it would be depicted if it were a stand-alone company.
The amount agreed by management that may be spent on a business case.

Request for additional or replacement head count that has been approved by all appropriate managers. The Data Warehouse gets information about approved head count from Webhire. In phase 1, that information is supplied monthly at the end of each month.
The amount of planned capital spending that has not yet been approved for specific business cases.
Gross sales of products or services.
This term is used in Oracle financials for any projection of financial results. Budget is not used except in reference to Oracle; see Forecast and Plan.
A sub-unit of a program (e.g., physical upgrade of data center). A business cases may be made up of a single project or several smaller but similar projects.

Business unit is a segment of the charge number and represents the organizational structure used for internal reporting and SEC segment reporting. There are multiple reporting levels (parents/children) within this charge code segment.
Capital Expenses

A business unit's point of contact for all capital management process related matters. The Capital Coordinator is responsible for coordinating all capital requests in their organization and serving as the capital management process interface with Corporate Finance. Capital Coordinators are located within the FP&A groups and have a dotted line reporting relationship to the comptroller.
For purposes of the FY03 capital management process, a capital planning business unit is a group within the organization that has capital budget accountability.

A Charge number is the concatenation of seven segments, separated by periods. The 7 segments, in order, are: company, business unit, department, natural account, product, intercompany, and future use. A sample charge number looks like this: 011.9000.5004.725010.0000.000.000000. A charge number is applied to every financial transaction and is used to identify the correct classification for financial reporting. Note: the future use segment currently defaults to all zeroes. The listing of all valid charge numbers is called the Chart of Accounts. Charge number is sometimes referred to as account or as charge code.
The listing of all charge number segments and their descriptions. The chart may also contain parents, thereby describing the hierarchy for each segment

The amount of capital expenditures that have been requested or ordered but not yet received. Open purchase requisitions (PRs) and purchase orders (POs) together make up the committed amount. If a PR or PO is cancelled, the amount is deducted from the committed amount.
A segment of the charge number and represents the legal entity being charged. Examples are: 011-Microsoft, Inc.

A Cost center is a subset of the entire charge number and concatenates 4 of the 7 segments. The cost center segments are: company, business unit, department, and product. The cost center is used to home employees in HR and is also used to simplify some online templates, like the Helpdesk.
Costs related to providing the goods or services driving revenue recognition. In other companies, this is sometimes referred to as Cost of Goods Sold.

The reporting classification of expenses. For example: Salary expenses related to marketing employees would have a cost type of S&M (sales and marketing). Salary expenses related to accounts receivable employees would have a cost type of G&A (general and administrative). For most expense accounts, the value of the Department segment determines the cost type; however, some natural accounts have a specific cost type regardless of Department.
Revenue to be recognized in a future period. It is computed as bookings minus recognized revenue.
A segment of the charge number and represents the functional classification being charged. Examples are: Engineering, Customer Service, Marketing, Finance, and Legal.

A quarterly projection or estimate of future revenue, earnings, and head count. After the annual financial plan is finalized, a forecast is developed in each subsequent quarter to update the projection based on new information. Each forecast covers the next twelve months, so these are sometimes referred to as rolling forecasts and reforecasts. The annual plan and the forecasts are stored in Oracle as budgets.
The total approved capital amount, usually stated in reference to a business unit or a program/priority area.
A commitment of capital dollars for the life of a program, assuming that program goals remain intact.
Revenues less cost of revenues. Also called gross margin when expressed as a percentage of revenues.
A segment of the charge number used to track all financial transactions across multiple legal entities (or companies). Upon consolidation, all intercompany accounts must total zero.
A segment of the charge number that determines what type of item was charged. Examples are: cash, amount payable, accrued expenses, airfare, salaries, training, advertising, registry fees, etc.
Revenues less returns and allowances.
Costs associated with the selling and administrative activities of the company.

Operating Income is defined as Net Sales less Operating Expenses (cost of goods sold, general & administrative expenses, sales & marketing expenses, research & development expenses, depreciation of property, plant & equipment and any recurring non-financing expenses associated with a company’s ongoing operations, (excluding interest payments, taxes & amortization of goodwill).
Revenues less cost of revenues and related operating expenses applying to the normal business activities of the company.

Operating Margin is defined as Operating Income divided by Net Sales, expressed as a percentage.  Operating Margin is a measure of the Company's ability to operate efficiently. The higher the operating margin, the better. It is used by the Company because it is a meaningful measure of how well management control expenses, and it is commonly used by the investment community to analyze and compare companies in the sectors in which the Company is engaged. It also facilitates year-over-year comparison of results, since operating margin excludes, among other things, unusual items that are not readily comparable from year to year.
Operating Expenses

The formal annual projection of future revenue, costs, and head count. The annual financial plan is reviewed and approved by the Board of Directors. Once the annual plan is approved. The company typically develops periodic forecasts to adjust for changes (see Forecast). The annual plan and the forecasts are stored in Oracle as budgets.
An annual projection of capital spending that has been approved by management. It is broken down by business unit and program/priority area.
The product segment of the charge number represents all products and services sold by the company.
Group of products or services that have a defined relationship because of physical and production similarities.

Each program will have a designated sponsor. The sponsor is responsible for ensuring that the business cases receiving program funding are executed as planned and taking corrective action if the program's performance goals are in jeopardy. The program sponsor is responsible for providing quarterly updates to Corporate Finance on (1) program milestones at risk, (2) explanations of significant budget variances and (3) forecasted expenditures to program completion.

Programs are capital investment spending categories that link to the business priorities outlined in the corporate capital plan. Capital is allocated to the business units at the program level. Once a program has been approved, the business unit has the authority to allocate the program capital to business cases best suited to fulfill the program's goals and objectives. There are four priorities and roughly 15 programs.

Each business case will have a designated project manager. The project manager is responsible for the day-to-day implementation of the project defined in the business case, including making sure that expenditures made against the business case are accurate and appropriate. The project manager is also responsible for providing quarterly updates to the Program Sponsor on (1) project milestones at risk, (2) explanations of significant budget variances and (3) forecasted expenditures to project completion.
see Forecast.

Process of recording revenue in the accounting period, after determining whether or not income has met the conditions of being earned and realized, or is realizable. In the period of revenue recognition, related expenses should be matched to revenue. Revenue is recognized at the time it is received or over the period it is incurred.
Received capital items, which may be in process (CIP), in service, or uninvoiced.
The sum of actual head count and approved head count.
Organization or company a user wants to track in SalesForce, for example, a customer, partner, or competitor.
Represents an individual account, which is an organization involved with your business (such as customers, competitors, and partners).
An account team is a team of users that work together on an account. For example, an account team may include an executive sponsor, dedicated support representative, or project manager.
Represents the role that a given Contact plays on an Account.
Represents a sharing entry on an Account.
Represents a User who is a member of an Account team.
Checkbox option that specifies the status of a user. An active user can log in and use the features of the service. An inactive user no longer has access to log in.
(Multi-Currency Organizations Only) The currencies in which the organization does business. Only active currencies can be entered in opportunities, forecasts, and other items.
Information displayed in company information that indicates the number of active users for your organization.
Planned task or event, optionally related to accounts, contacts, leads, opportunities, or cases.

Related list of account, contact, lead, opportunity, or case detail page that displays completed tasks, logged phone calls, expired events, outbound emails, and merged documents for the record and its associated records.
One or more individuals in your organization who can configure and customize SalesForce. Users assigned to the System Administrator profile have administrator privileges.

In opportunity reports, the Age of an open opportunity is the number of days since the opportunity was created. For closed opportunities, Age is the number of days between the creation date and the closed date. In case reports, the Age of an open case is the elapsed time from creation to the present. The Age of a closed case is the elapsed time from creation to the closing time of the case. You can choose to view the Age of a case in days, hours, or minutes.
Name that provides an alternate reference to an individual username. Used in displays when the username is too long.
See Schedule.
Represents an approval request for a Contract.

A specific model or type of product that a customer owns. Depending on how your organization uses assets, they can represent your products that the customer has purchased and installed or your competitor's products that the customer uses.
Represents an asset (such as product previously sold and installed) owned by an Account or Contact.
Represents an assignment rule associated with a Case or Lead.
Represents a file that a User has uploaded and attached to a parent object.
A custom field type that automatically adds a unique sequential number to each record. These fields are read only.

Revenue projection in a forecast that identifies total 'possible' revenue for a specific month or quarter. For managers, this should equal the total amount of revenue they and their entire team might possibly generate.
See Useful Links.

You can use Boolean operators in report filters to specify the logical relationship between two values. For example, the 'AND' operator between two values yields search results that include both values. Likewise, the 'OR' operator between two values yields search results that include either value. See Entering Filter Criteria for instructions on using 'AND' and 'OR' operators in report filters.
The set of data that you can manage offline using Offline Edition.
Represents a business process.
A marketing initiative, such as an advertisement, direct mail, or conference, that you conduct in order to generate prospects and build brand awareness.
Represents and tracks a marketing campaign, such as a direct mail promotion, webinar, or trade show.
Any lead or contact associated with a campaign.

The campaign ROI is the return on your marketing investment. Use the Campaign ROI Analysis Report to analyze the ROI. The ROI is calculated as the net gain (Total Value Won Opportunities - Actual Cost) divided by the Actual Cost. The ROI result is expressed as a percentage.
Represents the association between a Campaign and either a Lead or Contact.
Detailed description of a customer's feedback, problem, or question. Used to track and solve your customers' issues.
Represents a case, which is a customer issue such as a customer's feedback, problem, or question.
Functionality that lets you gather customer support issues and feedback on your company's website and then generate cases using that data.
Represents a comment that provides additional information about the associated Case.
Represents historical information about changes that have been made to the associated Case.
Represents the association between a particular Case and a particular Solution.
Represents the status of a Case, such as New, On hold, In Process, and so on.

A label you can apply to a solution to group similar solutions together. Solution categories help customer support representatives find solutions faster when solving cases. If you use the Self-Service portal or the Public Knowledge Base, your customers can browse solutions by category to find what they need. See also Parent Category.
Represents a logical grouping of Solution records.
Represents a tree of Solution categories.
Button or link that allows you to create a new item by copying the information from an existing item, for example, a contact or opportunity.
Estimated date to close an opportunity. The close date determines the month for which that opportunity is added to your forecast.

Calculated amount of closed/won opportunities for a given quarter. Displays on forecast detail and edit pages. For managers, this amount includes closed/won opportunities for them and their entire team.
Sections on detail pages that users can hide or show.

Amount entered in a forecast that an individual salesperson is reasonably confident of closing in a particular month or quarter. For managers, this should equal the amount that they and their team can confidently close.
Messages that appear on the home page of every user in your organization. Administrators can customize this information by clicking Setup | Customize | Home | Home Page Components.
Related list that displays competitor names, strengths, and weaknesses entered for a specific opportunity.
Information stored about the individuals associated with your accounts.
Represents a contact, which is an individual associated with your Accounts.

Role that a contact plays in a specific account, contract, or opportunity, for example Decision Maker, Evaluator. You can mark one contact as the 'primary' contact for the account, contract, or opportunity. A contact may have different roles in various accounts, contract, or opportunities.
A written agreement defining the terms of doing business between two or more parties.
Represents a contract (a business agreement) associated with an Account.
Represents the role that a given Contact plays on a Contract.
Represents the status of a Contract, such as Draft, In Approval, Activated, Terminated, or Expired.

Button or link that allows you to change a qualified lead into an account, contact, and, optionally, an opportunity. Information from the lead fields is transferred into the appropriate account, contact, and opportunity fields.

Client-specific data used by some web applications to store user and session-specific information. SalesForce issues a session 'cookie' only to record encrypted authentication information for the duration of a specific session.
(Multi-Currency Organizations Only) Reflects the currency in which the corporate headquarters reports revenue. All currency conversion rates are based on the corporate currency.
The country or geographic region in which the organization is located. This field affects the format and display of currency amounts. Not shown in organizations that use multiple currencies.
Represents the currencies used by an organization for which the multi-currency feature is enabled.
Fields that can be added in addition to the standard fields to customize SalesForce for your organization's needs.
Custom URLs defined by administrators to integrate your SalesForce data with external websites and back-office systems. Formerly known as web links.
Custom SalesForce records that allow you to store information unique to your organization. Available in Developer Edition organizations.

Custom web content for use in custom links. Custom s-controls can contain any type of content that you can display in a browser, for example a Java applet, an Active-X control, an Excel file, or a custom HTML web form.
See View.
A revised forecasting module that allows organizations to customize forecasts for their organization's business process.

Dashboards are visual representations of your custom report data. You can create several dashboard components within a dashboard to give you a real-time snapshot of corporate metrics and key performance indicators.

Parameter for number, currency, and percent custom fields that indicates the total number of digits you can enter to the right of a decimal point, for example, 4.98 for an entry of 2. Note that the system rounds the decimal numbers you enter, if necessary. For example, if you enter 4.986 in a field with Decimal Places of 2, the number rounds to 4.99.

The country or geographic region in which the organization is located. The setting affects the format of date and number fields. For example, dates in the English (United States) locale display as 06/30/2000 and as 30/06/2000 in the English (United Kingdom) locale. In Professional, Enterprise, and Developer Edition organizations, a user's individual Locale setting overrides the organization's Default Locale setting. In Personal and Team Edition organizations, the organization-level locale field is called Locale, not Default Locale.

Primary time zone in which the organization is located. Affects users' calendars and the times of activities. A user's individual Time Zone setting overrides the organization's Default Time Zone setting.
Field that can be used to include any detailed information about the item.

Information displayed for specific accounts, contacts, opportunities, and other records. Also, term used in reports to distinguish between summary information and inclusion of all column data for all information in a report. You can toggle the Show Details/Hide Details button to view and hide report detail information.
Product designed for developers to extend, integrate, and develop with the SalesForce platform. See Developer Edition for more information.
Represents a file that a user has uploaded. Unlike Attachment objects, Documents are not attached to a parent object.
A place to store documents without attaching them to accounts, contacts, opportunities, or other records.
Product designed for larger, more complex businesses. See Enterprise Edition.
Represents a calendar appointment event.
Represents a person (User, Contact, or Lead) who has been invited to attend an Event, or a scheduled resource (such as a conference room) associated with the event.
Option to save displayed report information to a separate CSV (comma separated values) file, which you can then view and manipulate in Excel.
Settings that determine whether fields are hidden, visible, read only, or editable for users based on their profiles. Available in Enterprise and Developer Editions only.
Field on the company information that specifies whether your organization's fiscal year is named for the starting or ending year.
Field on the company information that specifies the starting month of the organization's fiscal year.
A central place to store documents, email templates, and reports. Folders are available for all organizations. Report and document folders are not available in Personal Edition.
Represents a repository for a Document, MailMergeTemplate, email template, or report. Only one type of item can be contained in a particular Folder.
See Commit Amount.

Determines the category to which an opportunity is attributed in a forecast. The default category setting for an opportunity is tied to its stage, as set in the Stage picklist. To update the Forecast Category for a particular opportunity, you must edit that opportunity's forecast.
Projections of sales revenue based on quarters in the organization's fiscal year.
A type of custom field. Formula fields automatically calculate their values based on the values of merge fields, expressions, or other values.
Built-in formulas that you can customize with input parameters. For example, the DATE function creates a date field type from a given year, month, and day.
Represents a set of User.
Planned event to which multiple users are invited. You can create group events by inviting other users to any calendar event you create.
Represents a User or Group that is a member of a public group.

Groups are sets of users. They can contain individual users, other groups, or the users in a role. Groups can be used to help define sharing access to data or to specify which data to synchronize when using Intellisync for salesforce.com. Users can define their own personal groups. Administrators can create public groups for use by everyone in the organization.
Starting page from which users can choose sidebar shortcuts and options, view current tasks and activities, or select each of the major tabs.
Hypertext Markup Language is the set of markup tags within a text file that tells a browser how to display the contents of the file.
Option available to import existing information from other sales manager and desktop program tools.

(Multi-Currency Organizations Only) Currencies that the organization no longer uses. You may have existing records that use inactive currencies, but you cannot enter new amounts in inactive currencies.
Software you install on your computer that allows you to synchronize your SalesForce data with Outlook or your PalmTM device.
For report results based on time, a parameter that lets you specify the time period for which you want to display results.
The International Organization for Standardization country code, which represents each country by two letters.
See Page Layout.
Information on a potential sales opportunity or prospect; individuals who have expressed some interest in your product or company.
Represents a lead, which is a prospect or potential Opportunity.
Functionality that lets you gather registration or profile information on your company's website and then generate leads using that data.
Represents the status of a Lead, such as Open, Qualified, or Converted.

Parameter for custom text fields that specifies the maximum number of characters (up to 255) that a user can enter in the field. Parameter for number, currency, and percent fields that specifies the number of digits you can enter to the left of the decimal point, for example, 123.98 for an entry of 3.
Determines the basic attributes of an HTML email template. Users can create a letterhead that includes attributes like background color, logo, font size, and font color.
Information displayed in company information that indicates the number of users that may access SalesForce for your organization. This is the number of licenses for which you are billed.
The price of a product in a custom price book.
See View.
The value stored for the field in the user's or account's language. The local name for a field is associated with the standard name for that field.

The country or geographic region in which the user is located. The setting affects the format of date and number fields, for example, dates in the English (United States) locale display as 06/30/2000 and as 30/06/2000 in the English (United Kingdom) locale. In Professional, Enterprise, and Developer Edition organizations, a user's individual Locale setting overrides the organization's Default Locale setting. In Personal and Team Edition organizations, the organization-level locale field is called Locale, not Default Locale.
Data type of custom field that allows entry of up to 32,000 characters on separate lines.

Popup dialog available for some fields that allows you to search for a new item, such as a contact, account, or user. See Search for information on which fields you can search via the lookup dialog. In addition, if the Quick Create section is enabled for all tab home pages (see Customizing Quick Create), you can create new records in the lookup dialog.
Represents a mail merge template (a Microsoft Word document) used for performing mail merges for your organization.

One or more individuals in your organization who can manage campaigns. Administrators can designate someone as a Marketing User by selecting the Marketing User checkbox in the user's personal information. Only Marketing Users have access to create, edit, and delete campaigns and configure advanced campaign setup. In order to use the campaign import wizards, Marketing Users must also have the Marketing User profile (or the 'Import Leads' permission).
A complete list of picklist values available for a record type or business process.
The status of a lead or contact in relation to a campaign. For example, a lead or contact could have a member status of 'Planned,' 'Sent,' or 'Responded' at different stages of an email campaign.

Multiforce is the on-demand multitasking environment offered by salesforce.com. It enables users to switch between customizable applications (or 'apps') with a single click, through the Multiforce app menu which displays at the top of every page. See What is a Custom App?.
Field in opportunity detail that lists the next step in completing or closing a specific opportunity.
Represents a note, which is text associated with an Attachment, Contact, Contract, Opportunity, or custom object.
Miscellaneous information pertaining to specific accounts, contacts, leads, and opportunities.
Product that allows you to integrate SalesForce with Microsoft® Word and Excel. See What is Office Edition?.
Product that allows salespeople to work on their key deals and accounts, anywhere, anytime - totally unplugged. See What is Offline Edition?.
Product that allows salespeople to work on their key deals and accounts from a Pocket PC or Palm OS mobile device. See What is Offline PDA Edition?.
Area of Customforce that provides links to partners who provide products, services, and tools that extend your organization's implementation of SalesForce.
Information on specific sales and pending deals that you want to track.
Represents an opportunity, which is a sale or pending deal.
Status or stage of completion of a particular opportunity, for example, Prospecting, Proposal.
Represents a competitor on an Opportunity.
Represents the association between an Opportunity and a Contact, with a specified Role name applied to the contact.
Represents the history of an Opportunity.
Represents an opportunity line item, which is a member of the list of Product2s associated with an Opportunity, along with other information about those products on that opportunity.
Represents information about the quantity, revenue distribution, and delivery dates for a particular OpportunityLineItem.
Represents a sharing entry on an Opportunity.
Represents the stage of an Opportunity in the sales pipeline, such as New Lead, Negotiating, Pending, Closed, and so on.
Represents an individual User on the sales team of a particular Opportunity.

Ability to show a roll-up of results in a report based on your organization's role hierarchy. For instance, you can view report results for yourself only, for your team, or for your entire organization.
Company signed up to use the service.
Outlook Edition enables you to log your Microsoft® Outlook® email messages in SalesForce.
Individual user to which an item (for example, contact, case) is assigned.
Account field that describes whether the associated company is a subsidiary, or is a private or publicly held company.

The organization of fields, custom links, and related lists on a record detail or edit page. Use page layouts primarily for organizing pages for your users. In Enterprise and Developer Editions, use field-level security to restrict users' access to specific fields.

Organization or company that an account is affiliated with or owned by. By specifying a parent for an account, you can get a global view of all parent/subsidiary relationships using the View Hierarchy link.
The category directly above the category to which a solution belongs. See Category for more information.

Account linked to another account or opportunity to indicate their role in the account, or in advancing or closing a deal. Selecting a partner automatically creates a reverse partner relationship with the associated account so that both accounts list the other account as a partner.
Represents the association between two particular Accounts or between a particular Opportunity and an Account.
Selection for a partner on an individual account or opportunity that specifies the role that the partner has in related sales.
Represents a role for an account Partner, such as consultant, supplier, and so on.
Calculated value in forecasts that indicates what percentage of the quota a salesperson is confident of closing. This amount is the Commit Amount divided by the Quota.
(Multi-Currency Organizations Only) A user's default currency for quotas, forecasts, and reports. This must be one of the active currencies for your organization.
Product designed for individual sales representatives and single users. See Personal Edition for more information.
User information including personal contact information, quotas, personal group information, and default sales team.

Selection list of options available for specific fields, for example, the Industry field for accounts. Users can choose a single value from a list of options rather than make an entry directly in the field. See also Master Picklist.

Selection list of options available for specific fields. Multi-select picklists allow users to choose one or more values. Users can choose a value by double clicking on it, or choose additional values from a scrolling list by holding down the Control key while clicking a value and using the arrow icon to move them to the selected box.
Selections displayed in drop-down lists for particular fields. Some values come predefined, and other values can be changed or defined by an administrator.

Calculated amount of open opportunities that have a close date within the quarter. Displays on forecast detail and edit pages. For managers, this amount includes open opportunities for them and their entire team.
A list of products that your organization sells. Available in Professional, Enterprise and Developer Editions only.
Represents a price book that contains the list of Products that your organization sells.
Represents a price book that contains the list of Product2s that your organization sells.
Represents a product entry (an association between a Pricebook2 and Product2) in a pricebook.

Field in company information that lists the primary contact for your organization. Also indicates the primary contact associated with an account, contract, or opportunity. Specified as a checkbox in the Contact Roles related list of an account, contract, or opportunity.
Partner account designated as playing a key role in closing an opportunity. Specified as a checkbox in the Partners related list of an opportunity.
Option on most detail pages that shows a print-ready view of that record and all associated data. Also an option on reports that shows the report in a print-ready Excel format.
Checkbox for individual opportunities, notes, or attachments which specifies that only the record owner and administrators can view the information.
Percentage estimate of the confidence in closing a specific opportunity. Probability is linked to opportunity Stage.
Any item or service your organization sells. Products are defined within a price book, and can be added to opportunities. Available in Professional, Enterprise and Developer Editions only.
Represents a product that your organization sells. A product is member of the list of items in a Pricebook.
A picklist field on products that you can customize to categorize types of products.
Represents a product that your organization sells. A product is member of the list of items in a Pricebook2.
Product designed for businesses who need full-featured CRM functionality. See Professional Edition.
Defines a user's permission to perform different functions within SalesForce. For example, the Solution Manager profile gives a user access to create, edit, and delete solutions.
Represents a profile, which defines a set of permissions to perform different operations, such as querying, adding, updating, or deleting information.

A calendar in which a group of people can track events of interest to all of them (such as marketing events, product releases, or training classes) or schedule a common activity (such as a team vacation calendar). For example, your marketing team can set up an events calendar to show upcoming marketing events to the entire sales and marketing organization.
Checkbox on a solution that indicates the solution has been published to your organization's Self-Service portal.

Outlines the dates, number of units (i.e., quantity), and number of installments for billing or shipping a product. Your organization can decide exactly how to use schedules. Available in Enterprise and Developer Editions only.
A holding area where you can put cases or leads to help you manage your workload or differentiate between levels of support.
The revenue goal assigned to a user on a monthly and quarterly basis. A manager's quota should equal the amount she and her team are expected to generate together.

One of the standard profiles to which a user can be assigned. Read Only users can view and report on information based on their role in the organization. (That is, if the Read Only user is the CEO, they can view all data in the system. If the Read Only user has the role of Western Rep, they can view all data for their role and any role below them in the hierarchy.)
List of links in home page sidebar for most recently accessed accounts, campaigns, contacts, leads, opportunities, and cases.
Term used to describe information stored in the database. Corresponds to the entry of a particular item, for example, an account, opportunity, or case.

A field available for certain records that can include some or all of the standard and custom picklist values for that record. Record types are special fields that you can associate with profiles to make only the included picklist values available to users with that profile.
Represents a record type.
Page that lets you view and restore deleted information. Available as a link in the task bar below the tabs.
Section of a record or other detail page that lists items related to that record. For example, the Stage History related list of an opportunity or the Open Activities related list of a case.

A connection between two data-storage objects, used to create related lists in page layouts and detail levels in reports. Matching values in a specified field in both objects are used to link related data; for example, if one object stores data about companies and another object stores data about people, a relationship would allow you to find out which people work at the company.
Information you can display or print that provides a summary of your data.
Short, descriptive label for a user role that may be included in reports and other detail listings.
Name you can assign to a custom report when you save it.
Description of custom report that appears in the list of available custom reports.

Field in user role information that indicates the position they report to within an organization, for example, the California Sales Rep might report to a VP of Western Sales. Also, a contact field that refers to the contact's manager or supervisor.
A calendar in which multiple people can coordinate their usage of a shared resource such as a conference room or printer.
See On-Demand Marketplace.

Outlines the dates, revenue amounts, and number of installments for billing or recognizing revenue from a product. Your organization can decide exactly how to use schedules. Available in Enterprise and Developer Editions only.

Assigned responsibility of a user, partner account, or contact for specific accounts and opportunities. Administrators can define user roles in the organization setup. Individual users can assign specific partner and contact roles for accounts and contacts.
The price of a product on an opportunity. This can be different than the product's standard or list price.

A sales team is a set of users that normally work together on sales opportunities. A typical sales team might include the account manager, the sales representative, and a pre-sales consultant. You can specify the sales team for each opportunity that you own.
Button or link on most pages that you can click to save changes. Also, an option on reports that saves parameter changes to one of your own custom reports or a public report (administrators only).
Alternative 'save' on most pages with which you can save your current changes and create a new entry.
Option on any standard, public, or custom report to save the parameters of the report without altering the original report. It creates a new custom report with your saved changes.
See Quantity Schedule and Revenue Schedule.
Represents a custom s-control, which is custom content that is hosted by the server but executed by client applications.

Feature that lets you can search for information that matches specified keywords. You can enter a search from the Search section of the sidebar column, or perform an advanced search by clicking Advanced Search in the sidebar.
Condition on particular fields that qualifies items to be included in a view or report, for example, 'State equals California.'
The organization of fields included in search results, in lookup dialogs, and in the key lists on tab home pages.
A web portal feature that allows your customers to search your organization's knowledge base to find answers to their questions and to submit new cases to your customer support team.
Represents a Self-Service user.
See Custom S-Control.

Allowing other users to view or edit information you own. There are different ways to share data: Sharing Model - defines the default organization-wide access levels that users have to each other's information. Role Hierarchy - defines different levels of users such that users at higher levels can view and edit information owned by or shared with users beneath them in the role hierarchy, regardless of the organization-wide sharing model settings. See Notes on the Sharing Model for specific exceptions to this. Sharing Rules - allow an administrator to specify that all information created by users within a given group or role is automatically shared to the members of another group or role. Manual Sharing - allows individual users to share a specific account or opportunity with other users or groups.
See Groups.
Behavior defined by your administrator that determines default access by users to accounts, contacts, leads, and opportunities.

Type of default sharing created by administrators. Allows users in a specified group or role to have access to all information created by users within a given group or role. Sharing rules were previously called Autoshare Rules.
Option available for reports that lets you show/hide the details of individual column values in report results.
Column appearing on the left side of each page that provides links to search, recent items, and other resources.
Detailed description of the resolution to a customer issue.
Represents a solution, which is a detailed description of a customer issue and the resolution of that issue.

One or more individuals in your organization who can review, edit, publish, and delete solutions. Typically, these individuals are product experts with excellent written communication skills and advanced knowledge in a particular area of your product. When creating or editing users, assign the Solution Manager profile to give users this privilege.
Represents the status of a Solution, such as Draft, Reviewed, and so on.
See Opportunity Stage.
In opportunity reports, the number of days the opportunity was in the stage listed in the Stage column.
Related list on an opportunity detail page that lists changes in status and stage for the opportunity.
Price for a product that is included in the Standard Price Book.
Automatically generated price book containing all your products and their standard prices.
Field in activity or case detail that indicates progress or status.
Your personal settings that define what records are included when you synchronize. See Setting Your Sync Profile for instructions on setting your sync profile.
Transfer and merge your data with Outlook or your Palm device so that you can access critical information when you are not connected to the Internet.
Represents a task.
Links on tabbed pages that provide quick access to the most common operations available for a particular page, for example, creating a new account.
Represents the priority (importance) of a Task, such as High, Normal, or Low.
See Activity (Calendar Events/Tasks).
Represents the status of a Task, such as Not started, Completed, or Closed.
Product designed for small businesses and workgroups of up to five users. See Team Edition.
Data type of custom field that allows entry of any combination of letters, numbers, or symbols, up to a maximum length of 255 characters.
Data type of custom field that allows entry of up to 255 characters on separate lines.
See Long Text Area.

Primary time zone in which the user works. Used to coordinate a user's calendar, especially in organizations where users are working in different time zones. A user's individual Time Zone setting overrides the organization's Default Time Zone setting.

Administration setup area where your users can translate custom field names, picklist values, record types, and page layout sections. The translation workbench also determines which users translate different languages.
See Collapsible Sections.
Categorization of the type of an account or opportunity, for example, analyst, competitor, or partner for accounts and new or existing business for opportunities.
See Web Links.
Represents a user in your organization.
Represents a role in your organization.
Represents a single User on the default sales team of another user.
A list display of items (for example, accounts or contacts) based on specific criteria. SalesForce provides some predefined views, and you can create your own custom views, too.
Attribute of views that determines who in your organization can see and select a view.
See Custom Links.
See Custom Links.
Represents a web link to an URL or Scontrol.
A set of conditions based on any attribute of the case that determines the email template to use when responding to cases captured online.
A set of conditions based on any attribute of the lead that determines the email template to use when responding to leads captured online.
See Company Message.
An email template and recipient that a workflow rule uses when sending email alerts.
A set of conditions that, when met, assign tasks or send alerts in the form of email notifications.
A task template that determines the details of a task that will be automatically assigned by a workflow rule.
